author: bridge-bot
content:
<yoavw> > That makes sense, okay. Don't know where I got the idea that mempool clients would only forward txs for known paymasters.

It's permissionless but I can see where the confusion could come from.  Paymaster rules are more nuanced:
- If the paymaster doesn't need to access its own storage (only the account's), then it is accepted (and the UserOp is propagated). It has no way to DoS the mempool so it's equivalent to an account.
- If the paymaster does access its own storage, it could DoS the mempool by changing its behavior when used multiple times in the same bundle.  So it is only accepted and propagated if it locked a stake.  The stake serves as a sybil resistance mechanism, allowing nodes to keep a reputation and throttle paymasters that cause mass invalidations.
- A group of nodes may choose to form their own alt mempool where they waive this requirement and choose to trust a certain paymaster after auditing it. But this can't be done in the canonical mempool because the protocol is not opinionated about any specific paymaster.

I guess the confusion came from some people talking about the 3rd case.

> Either or. I'd prefer calling into the contract and leaving validation up to it, but whatever is feasible when we have to abandon ECDSA.

I think it would be important to invalidate the non-3074 use of the ECDSA key at the same time when 3074 replaces it.  Otherwise the compromised key could drain the account, bypassing the invoker. (re @SamWilsn: That makes sense, okay. Don't know where I got the idea that mempool clients would only forward txs for known paymasters.

> Does this mean abstracting the signature check to a contract, or just hardforking to add another signature scheme?

Either or. I'd prefer calling into the contract and leaving validation up to it, but whatever is feasible when we have to abandon ECDSA.)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<yoavw> Yes, so in 4337 that's the bundler.  The node in the AA mempool that picks the UserOp and puts it on chain (as part of a bundle).  The bundler uses an EOA, but can be QC resistant by using each EOA exactly once, so the system remains QC resistant even if Ethereum doesn't HF.

In 7560 there is no such entity, since we added it as a transaction type.  It's closer to how 2930 handled it.  So no ECDSA involved. (re @SamWilsn: I'm not familiar with the terminology. I mean the account whose balance is deducted at the start of the on-chain transaction.)
